function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Literature review does not cover all areas affected by the pandemic, leading to potential gaps in understanding contagious disease spread in different regions.","Impact":"Inadequate coverage may lead to insufficient understanding of disease spread patterns and risk factors in vulnerable populations.","Mitigation":"Collaborate with global research institutions and organizations to gather data from diverse regions and populations. Use advanced data analysis techniques to fill in knowledge gaps.","Technologies":"Data aggregation and analysis tools, collaboration platforms, advanced statistical and modeling software.","People":"Global research community, public health organizations, policymakers, researchers.","Owner":"Global research institutions, public health organizations, international collaboration initiatives."},{"Description":"Insufficient consideration of green housing policies and guidelines in the context of pandemic-related risks.","Impact":"Lack of appropriate policies may result in increased transmission of contagious diseases in built environments, risking public health.","Mitigation":"Develop and implement green housing policies that consider pandemic-related risks and prioritize measures to reduce disease transmission. Integrate public health expertise into green housing research and policy development.","Technologies":"Health risk assessment tools, building design and sanitation technologies, public health policy frameworks.","People":"Green housing researchers, policymakers, public health experts, urban planners.","Owner":"Government agencies, public health organizations, research institutions."},{"Description":"Limited application of comprehensive data analysis methods for understanding disease spread and its impact on built environments.","Impact":"Reduced ability to gain insights into the relationship between contagious diseases and built environments, hindering effective mitigation strategies.","Mitigation":"Leverage advanced data analysis techniques such as topic modeling, environmental psychology theory, and building life cycle methods to study disease spread in built environments. Integrate interdisciplinary expertise to enhance data analysis approaches.","Technologies":"Data analysis software, statistical modeling tools, interdisciplinary collaboration platforms.","People":"Data scientists, researchers, public health experts, urban planners.","Owner":"Research institutions, interdisciplinary research initiatives, public health organizations."}]}
